subs.text: March 8

@vhsvvitch The New Yorker excerpted Kael's review of Godfather (#1) recently in a podcast. What writing! The longer version on their website is also a powerhouse. She wrote a dazzling and damning review of John Wayne's "The Cowboys" movie, I recall. Start at 0:50. [link]

subs.text: I'd be pleased to buy writer @AdamLiptak a cup of coffee if I could ask whether the reporting hints at any influence of money in this NY policy. For-profit prisons, and maybe prisons others too, like to have full rosters and paying customers. [link]
subs.rawText:
I'd be pleased to buy writer @AdamLiptak a cup of coffee if I could ask whether the reporting hints at any influence of money in this NY policy. For-profit prisons, and maybe prisons others too, like to have full rosters and paying customers.
 https://t.co/z0a9fXhtE0

subs.text: 1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.
subs.rawText: 1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.

subs.text: 2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.
subs.rawText: 2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.

subs.text: 3/5 But they’d need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.
subs.rawText: 3/5 But they’d need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.

subs.text: 4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.
subs.rawText: 4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.

subs.text: 5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
subs.rawText: 5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.

subs.text: The National Weather Service explains the actual calculation of degree days for both cooling and heating. [link]
subs.rawText:
The National Weather Service explains the actual calculation of degree days for both cooling and heating.

https://t.co/V2XCknFYT8

subs.text: 3/3 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
subs.rawText: 3/3 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.

subs.text: 1/3 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days. The average hourly temperature in the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas they should have on hand to sell next March.
subs.rawText: 1/3 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days. The average hourly temperature in the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas they should have on hand to sell next March.

subs.text: 2/3 But they’d need a extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than the ten-year average. Each March has its own degree day total, when all is said and done.
subs.rawText: 2/3 But they’d need a extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than the ten-year average. Each March has its own degree day total, when all is said and done.

subs.text: Some mornings you open your eyes to eye-opening sentences and images on FB. “Pollution makes great sunsets.” “…like a true addict, I wanted all of my recovery to come at once.” “We stopped in Belize and visited a toucan sanctuary. It was my favorite part of the trip.” [link]

subs.text: A tweet got mucho readers, then @Twitter’s algo had Twitter’s brain ask me to sign up for the professional Twitter thing. I tried to see what in the world that actually means but the explanation web page neglected to explain. Bye, T-brain. Billing you for ten minutes of my life.
subs.rawText: A tweet got mucho readers, then @Twitter’s algo had Twitter’s brain ask me to sign up for the professional Twitter thing. I tried to see what in the world that actually means but the explanation web page neglected to explain. Bye, T-brain. Billing you for ten minutes of my life.

subs.text:
Responsibility
to renewable systems

would be a satisfying
and enduring cultural story

much better than our current one,

which glorifies the frantic 
and ecstatic strip-mining
of the planet’s resources,

crashing the natural systems
that make the resources
in the first place.
subs.rawText:

and enduring cultural story

much better than our current one,

which glorifies the frantic

of the planet’s resources,

crashing the natural systems
that make the resources
in the first place.

subs.text:
First day of spring semester, 1977, walking on a campus sidewalk. Ahead on the cement, I see a piece of paper money. Picked it up, looked around, said, “It’s a $100 bill.”

The young woman walking behind me said, “I should have gotten out of bed five minutes earlier today.”
subs.rawText:
First day of spring semester, 1977, walking on a campus sidewalk. Ahead on the cement, I see a piece of paper money. Picked it up, looked around, said, “It’s a $100 bill.”

The young woman walking behind me said, “I should have gotten out of bed five minutes earlier today.”

subs.text: March 3

1/3 The Stones are on the box, loud enough so I notice the drums. Next song, again it's the drums. I usually think the Stones are about the sting of the guitars and the backbone and sneer and syrup of the voice and the words, but no, tonight the drummer is the front man.
subs.rawText: 1/3 The Stones are on the box, loud enough so I notice the drums. Next song, again it's the drums. I usually think the Stones are about the sting of the guitars and the backbone and sneer and syrup of the voice and the words, but no, tonight the drummer is the front man.

subs.text: 2/3 Music teaches young people how to feel something, I think my sister said. Maybe that's the wound steel of the strings stretched and plucked, doing their part, but tonight the drums seem to say: don't just feel something, you'd better move.
subs.rawText: 2/3 Music teaches young people how to feel something, I think my sister said. Maybe that's the wound steel of the strings stretched and plucked, doing their part, but tonight the drums seem to say: don't just feel something, you'd better move.

subs.text: 3/3 The backbone, the attitude, well, we need that whenever we move out into the streets. The words might help us know why that is. Help us set sweet against bitter as we go.
subs.rawText: 3/3 The backbone, the attitude, well, we need that whenever we move out into the streets. The words might help us know why that is. Help us set sweet against bitter as we go.

subs.text: And then one of the cruel songs comes on.
subs.rawText: And then one of the cruel songs comes on.

subs.text: @cameronponsonby @blzzrd I grew up in a family of goalkeepers and goalie coaches in St. Louis, Missouri, one of the U.S.’s few real old football towns. Everyone I show this article to texts me saying, “Yes!” My brother’s son said, “Dad, you used to shout those same things at the TV when I was a kid.”

subs.text: March 1
